*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolishes the traditional common-law distinction between invitees and licensees in Massachusetts and replaces it with a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners/occupiers to lawful entrants. That principle squarely supports the proposition that a landlord/property manager owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain common areas, like hallways and stairwells, in a reasonably safe condition for lawful occupants. Although the quoted text is from a concurrence and discusses trespassers, the case as a whole is authoritative for the stated duty to lawful occupants.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: We now hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The appropriate test to be applied henceforth in determining the liability of an occupier of land is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others. This duty of reasonable care is owed to all lawful visitors.

*Dos Santos v. Coleta*, 465 Mass. 148 (2.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … It also includes an obligation ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’”

*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord who retains control over common areas owes tenants a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep those areas in a reasonably safe condition.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..support_reasoning: The court squarely abandons the prior Massachusetts rule and adopts the modern rule that a landlord retaining control of common areas owes a general, continuing duty of reasonable care to tenants, just as to their visitors. The opinion explicitly endorses Restatement (Second) of Property § 17.3, which states that a landlord is liable for dangerous conditions in areas retained under his control if, by reasonable care, he could have discovered and made them safe. This directly matches the claimed proposition about a duty to keep common areas reasonably safe.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
“We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ in kind from that owed by the landlord to the tenant’s visitors….

The quoted passage is taken from the Reporter’s note to Restatement (Second) of Property — Landlord & Tenant § 17.3…: ‘A landlord who leases a part of his property and retains in his own control any other part the tenant is entitled to use…is subject to liability…if the landlord by the exercise of reasonable care could have…made the condition safe.’”

Eagle Brook Country Store, I.support_reasoning: The court explicitly addresses the effect of violating G.L. c. 138, § 69, and reaffirms Massachusetts law that such a statutory violation is not negligence per se but is "some evidence" of negligence. This aligns directly with the proposition that violation of such safety statutes and regulations constitutes evidence of negligence, not conclusive proof. The opinion therefore supports the claimed proposition.
*Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, I.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. … Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant’s negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

*Perry v. Medeiros*, 369 Mass. 836, 841.proposition: Violation of such safety statutes and regulations constitutes evidence of negligence.
*Perry v. Medeiros*, 369 Mass. 836, 841.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the Massachusetts rule that violation of a safety statute or ordinance does not itself create a cause of action but is evidence of negligence, and applies that rule to the excluded building code provision. The court explains that a jury could find a building code violation that contributed to the injury and that such a violation is evidentiary on negligence, directly matching the claimed proposition.
*Perry v. Medeiros*, 369 Mass. 836, 841.relevant_excerpt: “With the benefit of the excluded portion of § 6.08 the jury could have found that there was a violation of the building code which contributed to the plaintiff’s injury. ‘The general rule in Massachusetts is that violation of the safety statute or ordinance does not in itself give rise to a cause of action but is evidence of negligence.’ Dolan v. Suffolk Franklin Sav. Bank, 355 Mass. 665, 667 (1969). It is also the general rule that while the violation of a safety statute, ordinance or regulation is not conclusive on the issue of civil liability, it ‘…is evidence of negligence….’”}

Hayden, Harding & Buchanan, In.support_reasoning: The case is not about landlord liability or common areas; it concerns an employer’s duty to provide a safe workplace, tools, and warnings to an experienced boiler operator. The court holds there was no evidence of negligence under Massachusetts common law on these facts. Citing this opinion to show that the defendant’s breaches constitute negligence misstates the holding, which actually finds no negligence.
*Janes v. Hayden, Harding & Buchanan, In.relevant_excerpt: Since the defendant was not insured under the workmen’s compensation act the only question raised by the direction of a verdict is whether there was evidence of negligence of the defendant, as alleged in the declaration, which contributed to cause the plaintiff’s injury. … It was not negligent for the defendant to set a man of the plaintiff’s admitted knowledge and experience at work in the boiler room without further instructions or to fail to warn him of the increase in quantity or the change in the characteristics of the clinkers which would result from the use of the fuel provided… There being no evidence of negligence of the defendant judgment must be entered on the verdict.

It therefore does not affirm that the defendant’s conduct constituted negligence; if anything, it supports the opposite result in this case.
*Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co.*, 400 M.relevant_excerpt: “The question is whether, as a matter of law, Arco’s failure to erect a sign warning customers to be on guard against other vehicles did not unreasonably increase the risk of injury caused by the improper operation of other vehicles on the premises. I agree with the court that the evidence did not present a jury question.… In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns duty and scope of foreseeable risk in a medical‑malpractice context and does not involve premises liability, inspections, or maintenance of safety devices like smoke detectors. Although it discusses foreseeability in the context of causation, it does not hold that a defendant remains liable where a third party’s foreseeable intervening act (such as removing a battery) should have been discovered and remedied by reasonable inspection. The case therefore does not provide authority for the specific proposition about inspections and intervening acts not breaking the chain of causation.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.relevant_excerpt: “The law does not impose liability for all harm factually caused by tortious conduct. Liability for conduct obtains only where the conduct is both a cause in fact of the injury and where the resulting injury is within the scope of the foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct. … While a third party nonpatient directly injured by a medicated patient who drives an automobile from a hospital may be within the scope of foreseeable risk, a police officer injured in an accident in which the patient is not involved is outside that scope.”
